column2: published in [[1949]]) is a short story written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]].  The story describes a series of encounters between [[Farmer Giles]] and a wily dragon named [[Chrysophylax]]. It is set in a fantasy Britain of long ago

column1: The book was originally illustrated by [[Pauline Baynes]].
Farmer Giles was not a hero. He was fat and red-bearded and enjoyed a slow
column2: comfortable life. One day a rather deaf and short-sighted [[The Giant|giant]] blundered on to his land. Farmer Giles managed to scare him away with a [[blunderbuss]] shot in its general direction. The people of the village cheered: Farmer Giles was a hero.

column1: His reputation spread far and wide across the kingdom. Giles was rewarded by the King of the [[Middle Kingdom]]
The giant reported to its monstrous friends that there were no more knights
column2: just stinging flies (actually scrap metal from Giles' blunderbuss)
column3: in the Middle Kingdom. This prompted a dragon
column5: to investigate the area — and everyone turns to the accidental hero Farmer Giles to deal with it.

column1: The story makes light of the great dragon-slaying traditions. The knights who are supposed to do the job  are useless fops more intent on "precedence and etiquette" than on noticing huge dragon footprints littering the landscape. "Giles" is also an interesting commentary on how people react to danger. Heroes aren't simply called for
column2: they are demanded and hapless farmers can be forced to be heroes.

column1: The Latin names and references imply that Giles is a Briton
column2: a late generation remnant of the old empire after the decline of the western authority of the Romans. All the Giles place-names are supposed to occur relatively close to Oxford
column3: along the Thames or on the route from London to Oxford.

column2: on which he had worked. The phrase 'wise clerk of Oxenford' is also a reference to Chaucer's Clerk.
